passages.text: Quest thematic allocation framework update: Al and fintech remain strategic priorities, adaptive hedging strategies and implementation ideas

AI and Fintech as Thematic Strategic Priorities: We provide an update on our Quest thematic allocation framework since its debut in January 2025. The framework continues to emphasize AI and Fintech as key themes, with overweight positions in semiconductors, software, and capital markets. These segments remain attractive due to favorable growth and price trends, driven by advancements in AI infrastructure and monetization, alongside the rising adoption of blockchain solutions. This year, thematic strategies face challenges such as policy uncertainty and market volatility. However, investors should remain confident in these strategic allocations, as they position the portfolio to capture long- term potential in these high- growth areas.

Dynamically Hedging Market Risks with Term Structure Signals: To better navigate market volatility, we employ a dynamic hedging strategy guided by volatility term structure signals. When markets appear oversold, indicated by a sharp inversion in the implied volatility term structure, we reduce short exposure in MSCI World futures. This approach balances downside protection with the flexibility to capitalize on market rebounds. Since 2014, the dynamic long- short strategy has improved the CAGR/Vol ratio to 0.61 compared to 0.38 for the static version. This approach also performed well in April this year, resulting in an \(8.3\%\) year- to- date return, compared to \(2.9\%\) for the static long- short strategy.

Capturing Policy Tailwinds and AI Momentum via Tech ETFs (SMH/ SOXX/XLK) and Custom Baskets: Semiconductors and software remain the highest- ranked sectors in our Quest thematic allocation framework, supported by strong growth fundamentals and price momentum. According to our US Equity Strategy team, the OBBBA adds a clear policy tailwind, with immediate expensing of capex and R&D expected to deliver meaningful tax benefits while reinforcing the ongoing AI and datacenter investment cycle. Investors can gain exposure through ETFs such as SMH, SOXX, and XLK, or via our custom baskets targeting expensing beneficiaries (JPGTIEXB ) and AI/Datacenter infrastructure (JPAIMAIDE ) (link). Options markets in these ETFs continue to trade rich to realized with steep put- call skew, creating favorable conditions for short- volatility structures. In terms of derivatives implementation, we highlight accumulators on ETFs and call spread collars on both ETFs and baskets as efficient ways to capture upside while monetizing volatility and skew premia.

The Quest thematic allocation framework can be applied to custom portfolio holdings comprising of baskets, ETFs and indices. For investors interested in tailored analysis, please contact us for further details.
See page 12 for analyst certification and important disclosures.

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

The Quest thematic allocation framework systematically explores investment opportunities by integrating growth potential and price trends, while adjusting to factors like news popularity and liquidity (see here). The framework can be applied to custom portfolio holdings. This report provides an update on the framework's performance and current signals using sector portfolios. By using sector portfolios as proxies for thematic investments, we aim to minimize survival bias and leverage a more comprehensive historical data set for trend analysis.

In the first 7 months of 2025, our Quest thematic allocation framework has demonstrated performance that is in line with the global equity market, with a year- to- date return of \(10.9\%\) , aligning with the broader MSCI World Index (Figure 1). Since 2014, the strategy has maintained an annualized return of \(13.2\%\) and a CAGR/volatility ratio of 0.84, compared to \(10\%\) and 0.68 for the MSCI World (Figure 2).

Our Quest thematic allocation framework emphasizes AI and Fintech as key thematic priorities this year, with overweight positions in Semiconductors, Software, and Capital Markets (Table 1). These sectors are attractive due to favorable growth and price trends, driven by advancements in AI infrastructure and monetization, alongside the rising adoption of blockchain solutions. Despite challenges such as policy uncertainty and market volatility this year, investors should remain confident in these strategic allocations, as they position the portfolio to capture long- term potential in these high- growth areas.

The strategy continues to emphasize AI and Fintech as its strategic priorities, with high allocation in Semiconductors, Software, and Capital Markets. These sectors remain attractive due to favorable growth and price trends. Based on our analysis of news data, Capital Markets is linked to blockchain and fintech adoption, while Semiconductors are associated with cloud computing and AI infrastructure, and Software is tied to AI applications and cybersecurity (Table 3). The ongoing excitement around artificial intelligence has spotlighted AI infrastructure and monetization, driving gains in semiconductors and related software. At the same time, the rise of cryptocurrencies, stablecoins, and digital platforms has boosted Capital Markets, reflecting how financial technology continues to reshape investor behavior. Together, these sectors have significantly contributed to performance, anchoring the strategy to themes with long- term potential in high- growth areas.

The scorecard generated from the thematic allocation framework can assist investors in determining which themes to consider and when to take action. It serves as a tool for guiding thematic asset allocation strategies.

Why this matters: Investors often encounter difficulties in selecting themes and timing their investments. The scorecard addresses this challenge by offering a structured framework for evaluating themes, reducing reliance on subjective

**How it helps investors:** The scorecard provides a comparative ranking of themes based on core factors such as growth potential, earnings revisions, and price trends. Adjustments for liquidity-related signals, like news popularity and liquidity, make the scorecard responsive to changes in market conditions. This approach helps investors prioritize themes with strong potential while considering current market influences.

**How to read it:** Each theme is scored across the core factors of the framework. Themes with higher composite scores represent stronger investment opportunities based on both fundamental and market-driven criteria. The scorecard also includes trend indicators, offering guidance on whether a theme's attractiveness is rising or declining, providing actionable insights for portfolio allocation.
For more details, please refer to **Introducing the Quest thematic allocation framework**

While AI and fintech remain the core of the strategy, we recognize the risks of sharp market corrections. In April 2025, for instance, tariff threats from the Trump administration triggered a \(17\%\) market drop, and our strategy experienced a deeper drawdown of \(21\%\) . To better navigate such episodes, we employ a dynamic hedging overlay using volatility term structure signals.

Unlike a static hedge, which maintains a constant short position in MSCI World futures, this approach scales hedge exposure according to market conditions. When markets appear oversold—indicated by a sharp inversion in the implied volatility term structure (1Y- 3M ATM vol spread \(Figure 4: Integrating term structure signal into the hedging mechanism can help capture the rebound after market stress periods
Source: RavenPack, J.P. Morgan Equity Derivatives Strategy; Bloomberg Finance L.P.
Figure 5: YTD performance history of Quest allocation long-short strategy with and without term structure signal
Source: RavenPack, J.P. Morgan Equity Derivatives Strategy; Bloomberg Finance L.P. Note: Past performance is not an indicator of future results

Methodology: We back- tested the effectiveness of term structure signal in long- short strategy. The default setting is keeping \(100\%\) of hedge on all the time, while using term structure signal to tell us when to reduce hedge. To be more
conservative, we only take off \(50\%\) of the hedge when the signal is triggered. That said, we always have at least \(50\%\) of the hedge on top of the strategy.
- **Short instrument**: MSCI World futures
- **Rebalance frequency of the short leg**: We adjust the notional of the short leg on a weekly basis to match that of long leg.
- **Benchmark**: Keep \(100\%\) of hedge on all the time, i.e., we match the notional of the short leg with the long leg every week.

Note: Data as of Jul 31, 2025. Past performance is not an indicator of future results
Source: J.P. Morgan Equity Derivatives Strategy; Bloomberg Finance L.P.

Since 2020, the term structure signal has been particularly effective, capturing rebounds following drawdowns and resulting in a \(27.4\%\) return for the long- short strategy utilizing the signal, compared to \(11.4\%\) for the strategy without it. This approach also performed well in April this year, resulting in an \(8.3\%\) year- to- date return, compared to \(2.9\%\) for the static hedging strategy. This demonstrates the term structure signal's ability to enhance returns by dynamically adjusting to market conditions.

Semiconductor and software stocks continue to carry the heaviest weights in our Quest thematic allocation framework. These sectors consistently rank at the top in both growth characteristics and price momentum, and the alignment of fundamentals with price signals has kept them as structural overweight positions in our model. Their leadership within the framework reflects both durability of earnings growth and resilience of market trends.

The One Big Beautiful Bill Act (OBBBA) provides a thematic tailwind that complements this positioning (see here). Its immediate expensing provisions for capital expenditures and R&D are expected to generate significant tax savings for capital- intensive industries, with particular benefit to technology hardware, software, and AI- related companies. The timing of these provisions is especially relevant, as they overlap with an ongoing wave of AI and datacenter investment in which semiconductors remain at the core. Together, these dynamics suggest that the OBBBA will act as a sector- level catalyst over the next 6 to 18 months, reinforcing the signals captured by the Quest framework with a clear policy driver.
Figure 6: Semiconductor and Software industry weights for major tech ETFs and custom baskets
Based on GICS Industry (level 3) Source: J.P. Morgan Equity Derivatives Strategy; Bloomberg Finance L.P.
Figure 7: YTD performance for major tech ETFs and custom baskets
Source: J.P. Morgan Equity Derivatives Strategy; Bloomberg Finance L.P. Note: Past performance is not an indicator of future results

In listed markets, ETFs such as SMH, SOXX, and XLK provide liquid access to these sectors, along with a liquid options markets. In addition, investors may consider our Immediate Expensing Beneficiaries basket (JPGTIEXB Index) and AI/Datacenter basket (JPAMAIDE Index), which target these themes more directly. While options are not listed on the baskets, we can implement OTC options or swaps to gain exposure. Please refer to the report for more detailed basket construction methodology.

From a pricing standpoint, options markets in SMH, SOXX, and XLK display conditions that favor strategies with a short- volatility and short- skew bias. Long- dated implied volatility trades at a premium to realized, while skew has steepened on persistent hedging demand ahead of upcoming policy events including the NFP (9/5) and the FOMC (9/18). The gap between 1Y ATM implied and 1M realized is 2.0 vol in SOXX, 2.8 vol in SMH, and 0.9 vol in XLK. These dynamics allow investors to extract value from option premia while retaining exposure to sector upside.
Figure 8: Implied and realized volatility history for major tech ETFs
Source: J.P. Morgan Equity Derivatives Strategy; Bloomberg Finance L.P.

An accumulator is one implementation for ETFs, allowing investors to build long exposure at discounted levels while systematically monetizing rich implied volatility. The structure benefits from low realized volatility: if the underlying remains range- bound, the discount embedded at inception is locked in.
Figure 9: Indicative pricing for accumulators
UnderlyingGuaranteed PeriodsSettlement FrequencyTenor (m)KO (%)Strike(%)SMH US1mWeekly1210584.12SOXX US1mWeekly1210586.63XLK US1mWeekly1210590.14

Prices as of 26 August 2025. Accumulators: 1Y maturity, 2x leverage below strike level, monthly settlement, client receives 50bps upfront Knockout at \(105\%\) , the guaranteed period in an accumulator ensures that if a knockout event occurs within this timeframe, the client will receive a predetermined number of shares at the strike price. Source: J.P. Morgan Equity Derivatives Strategy; Bloomberg Finance L.P.

For both ETFs and baskets, a call spread collar is a natural alternative. By selling a put and buying a call spread, investors monetize expensive downside skew to fund upside participation. A variation can embed barriers to improve cost efficiency—for example, selling a knock- in put while buying a knock- out call. Setting the knock- in barrier at a distant out- of- the- money level allows investors to capture volatility premium while keeping the likelihood of barrier activation low. Meanwhile, the knock- out condition on the call reduces premium outlay while maintaining meaningful upside exposure up to the barrier.
Figure 10: Indicative pricing for buying a call spread and selling a put at zero cost

We prefer buying swaps to gain exposure to our Immediate Expensing Beneficiaries basket (JPGTIEXB Index), as the pricing of a call spread collar on the basket is not attractive given the basket's low implied volatility.

Risks to Strategies: Not all option strategies are suitable for investors; certain strategies may expose investors to significant potential losses. We have summarized the risks of selected derivative strategies. For additional risk information, please call your sales representative for a copy of "Characteristics and Risks of Standardized Options." We advise investors to consult their tax advisors and legal counsel about the tax implications of these strategies. Please also refer to option risk disclosure documents.

Put Sale: Investors who sell put options will own the underlying asset if the asset's price falls below the strike price of the put option. Investors, therefore, will be exposed to any decline in the underlying asset's price below the strike potentially to zero, and they will not participate in any price appreciation in the underlying asset if the option expires unexercised.
Call Sale: Investors who sell uncovered call options have exposure on the upside that is theoretically unlimited.

Call Overwrite or Buywrite: Investors who sell call options against a long position in the underlying asset give up any appreciation in the underlying asset's price above the strike price of the call option, and they remain exposed to the downside of the underlying asset in the return for the receipt of the option premium.

Booster: In a sell- off, the maximum realized downside potential of a double- up booster is the net premium paid. In a rally, option losses are potentially unlimited as the investor is net short a call. When overlaid onto a long position in the underlying asset, upside losses are capped (as for a covered call), but downside losses are not.

Collar: Locks in the amount that can be realized at maturity to a range defined by the put and call strike. If the collar is not costless, investors risk losing \(100\%\) of the premium paid. Since investors are selling a call option, they give up any price appreciation in the underlying asset above the strike price of the call option.
Call Purchase: Options are a decaying asset, and investors risk losing \(100\%\) of the premium paid if the underlying asset's price is below the strike price of the call option.
Put Purchase: Options are a decaying asset, and investors risk losing \(100\%\) of the premium paid if the underlying asset's price is above the strike price of the put option.

Straddle or Strangle: The seller of a straddle or strangle is exposed to increases in the underlying asset's price above the call strike and declines in the underlying asset's price below the put strike. Since exposure on the upside is theoretically unlimited, investors who also own the underlying asset would have limited losses should the underlying asset rally. Covered writers are exposed to declines in the underlying asset position as well as any additional exposure should the underlying asset decline below the strike price of the put option. Having sold a covered call option, the investor gives up all appreciation in the underlying asset above the strike price of the call option.

Put Spread: The buyer of a put spread risks losing \(100\%\) of the premium paid. The buyer of higher- ratio put spread has unlimited downside below the lower strike (down to zero), dependent on the number of lower- struck puts sold. The maximum gain is limited to the spread between the two put strikes, when the underlying is at the lower strike. Investors who own the underlying asset will have downside protection between the higher- strike put and the lower- strike put. However, should the underlying asset's price fall below the strike price of the lower- strike put, investors regain exposure to the underlying asset, and this exposure is multiplied by the number of puts sold.

Call Spread: The buyer risks losing \(100\%\) of the premium paid. The gain is limited to the spread between the two strike prices. The seller of a call spread risks losing an amount equal to the spread between the two call strikes less the net premium received. By selling a covered call spread, the investor remains exposed to the downside of the underlying asset and gives up the spread between the two call strikes should the underlying asset rally.

Butterfly Spread: A butterfly spread consists of two spreads established simultaneously - one a bull spread and the other a bear spread. The resulting position is neutral, that is, the investor will profit if the underlying is stable. Butterfly spreads are established at a net debit. The maximum profit will occur at the middle strike price; the maximum loss is the net debit.
Pricing Is Illustrative Only: Prices quoted in the above trade ideas are our estimate of current market levels, and are not indicative trading levels.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. To the extent that any ETFs are mentioned in this report, JPMS may earn commissions and transaction- based compensation in connection with the distribution of those ETF shares and may earn fees for performing other trade- related services, such as securities lending to short sellers of the ETF shares. JPMS may also perform services for the ETFs themselves, including acting as a broker or dealer to the ETFs. In addition, affiliates of JPMS may perform services for the ETFs, including trust, custodial, administration, lending, index calculation and/or maintenance and other services.

of, or income from, any investments referred to in this material may fluctuate and/or be affected by changes in exchange rates.
